H0.text: Life cycles are haploid-dominant in fungi such as black bread mold (rhizopus nigricans).

H1.text: Birth cycles are haploid-dominant in fungi such as black bread mold (Rhizopus nigricans).

H2.text: Gene pools are haploid-dominant in fungi, such as black bread mold (Rhizopus nigricans).

H3.text: Mutations are haploid-dominant in fungi such as black bread mold (Rhizopus nigricans).

A4.text: Most fungi have both a haploid and a diploid stage in their life cycles.

A5.text: In sexual reproduction, a dark zygospore is produced at the point where two compatible mycelia fuse.

A6.text: Upon germination, a zygospore produces colonies that are genetically different from either parent.

A7.text: In opisthokonts: most fungi (some chytrids, zygomycetes, some ascomycetes, basidiomycetes)

A8.text: In the whole cycle, zygotes are the only diploid cell; mitosis occurs only in the haploid phase.

A9.text: Most fungi and algae are haploid during the principal stage of their life cycle, as are some primitive plants like mosses.
